Adapting Differentially Private Synthetic Data to Relational Databases

Kaveh Alimohammadi1∗, Hao Wang2  , Ojas Gulati1, Akash Srivastava2, Navid Azizan1
1MIT   2MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab Equal contribution. Emails: {mrz,azizan,ojasg}@mit.edu, {hao,akash.srivastava}@ibm.com. This is a working paper. Comments to improve this work are welcome.
Abstract

Existing differentially private (DP) synthetic data generation mechanisms typically assume a single-source table. In practice, data is often distributed across multiple tables with relationships across tables. In this paper, we introduce the first-of-its-kind algorithm that can be combined with any existing DP mechanisms to generate synthetic relational databases. Our algorithm iteratively refines the relationship between individual synthetic tables to minimize their approximation errors in terms of low-order marginal distributions while maintaining referential integrity. Finally, we provide both DP and theoretical utility guarantees for our algorithm.

1 Introduction

Relational databases play a pivotal role in modern information systems and business operations due to their efficiency in managing structured data [39]. According to a Kaggle survey [23], 65.5% of users worked extensively with relational data. Additionally, the majority of leading database management systems (e.g., MySQL and Oracle) are built on relational database principles [35]. These systems organize data into multiple tables, each representing a specific entity, and the relationships between tables delineate the connections between these entities. However, the widespread use of relational databases also carries a significant risk of privacy leakage. For example, if a single table suffers from a privacy breach, all other tables containing sensitive information can be exposed, as they are interconnected and share relationships. Moreover, deleting data in a relational database can be complex, and incomplete deletion can leave traces of data, which can potentially be accessed and reconstructed by attackers.

Today, differential privacy (DP) stands as the de facto standard for privacy protection. There is a growing body of research focused on applying DP to generate private synthetic data [see, e.g., 36, 31, 27, 41]. This effort enables data curators to share (synthetic) data while ensuring the privacy of individuals’ personal information within the original dataset. In return, they can harness advanced machine learning techniques employed by end-users trained on the synthetic data. Numerous studies have provided evidence that state-of-the-art (SOTA) DP synthetic data effectively preserves both the statistical properties of the original data and the high performance of downstream predictive models trained on these synthetic datasets when deployed on the original data [45, 51]. However, all existing works assume a single-source database (with a few exceptions discussed in Related Work). It motivates the central question we aim to tackle in this paper:

Can we adapt existing DP synthetic data generation algorithms to relational databases while preserving their referential integrity?

The conventional approach—flattening relational databases into a single master table, generating a synthetic master table, and dividing it into separate databases—presents several challenges. To illustrate, consider education data as an example, with two tables (student and teacher information) linked by students’ enrollment in a teacher’s course. First, flattening often introduces numerous null values, complicating the differentiation between missing and intentionally null data. If a teacher isn’t teaching, student information in the master table will show up as null, even if the original tables had none. Second, flattening creates scalability and redundancy issues. Records in the master table often contain a high number of features, leading to longer running times for SOTA DP synthetic data generation algorithms as features increase [e.g., 32, 31, 50, 1]. Moreover, records from the original tables can be duplicated across entries, increasing redundancy and storage demand. Finally, breaking down a synthetic master table may disrupt relationships when shared feature values are involved. For instance, if the master table contains two courses with students sharing identical demographic data, it’s unclear if they’re the same student or different individuals with matching details.

Our goal is to introduce the first-of-its-kind algorithm that can generate synthetic relational databases while preserving the privacy, statistical properties, and referential integrity of the original data. For this purpose, we first discuss DP in relational databases, extend the definition of k𝑘k-way marginal queries [46, 36] to relational databases, and articulate the requirements of referential integrity (Section 2). The main technical contribution is introducing an iterative algorithm that effectively learns the relationship between various tables (Section 3). At each iteration, the algorithm identifies a subset of k𝑘k-way marginal queries with the highest approximation errors and then refines the relational synthetic database to minimize these errors. Notably, our algorithm avoids the need to flatten relational databases into a master table; instead, it only requires querying the relational databases to compute low-order marginal distributions, which can be done using SQL aggregate functions. Consequently, we can leverage any off-the-shelf DP mechanisms to generate synthetic data for individual tables and apply our algorithm to establish their inter-table relationship. We analyze our algorithm theoretically, establishing both DP and utility guarantees.

Existing literature on synthetic relational data generation, even without DP guarantees, remains limited [29, 34, 53, 14, 10, 54].

In summary, our contributions include:

  • •

    Presenting a pioneering study on privacy-preserving synthetic data generation in relational databases.

  • •

    Introducing an iterative algorithm that establishes relationships between synthetic tables while preserving statistical properties and referential integrity.

  • •

    Developing a model-agnostic approach that integrates with any DP synthetic data algorithm, offering both privacy and utility guarantees.

Related Work

Privacy-preserving synthetic data generation is an active research topic [see e.g., 5, 47, 6, 11, 16, 37, 51]. For example, a line of work considered learning probabilistic graphical models [55, 30, 31] or generative adversarial networks [52, 2, 22, 44, 33, 3] with DP guarantees and generating synthetic data by sampling from these models. Another line of work proposed to iteratively refine synthetic data to minimize its approximation error on a pre-selected set of workload queries [18, 15, 32, 27, 26, 49, 1, 50, 28]. They only focused on a single-source dataset without considering relational database. The only exceptions are [53, 10]. [10] used graphical models for generating DP synthetic data, incorporating latent variables to capture the primal-foreign-key relationship. However, their method is limited to one-to-many relationships while our method can handle relationships of any type. A more closely related work is [53], which can produce multiple tables with many-to-many relationships by leveraging tools from random graph theory and representation learning. However, their method required using DP-SGD to optimize their generative models for each table generation, whereas our method can seamlessly integrate with any existing DP mechanisms for synthetic table generation. This versatility is essential, particularly as marginal-based and workload-based mechanisms often produce higher-quality synthetic tabular data than DP-SGD-based mechanisms [45, 31, 51]. Finally, some research explored DP in relational database systems, primarily focusing on releasing statistical queries [see e.g., 20, 21, 24]. In contrast, our emphasis is on releasing a synthetic copy of the relational database, extending the scope of privacy-preserving data generation methods to a more practical and general setting.

Another line of work focused on the release of DP synthetic graphs [25, 56, 13, 48, 17, 4, 38, 19] with the goal of maintaining essential graph properties (e.g., connectivity, degree distribution, and cut approximation). While a relational database can often be represented as a multipartite graph (see Section 2.1), applying these existing approaches to generate synthetic relational databases encounters various challenges. First, these methods often assume that the vertex set of both real and synthetic graphs is common, learning the edge set through DP mechanisms. In our scenario, however, the vertex sets (representing records) of real and synthetic databases differ, requiring privacy preservation for both the vertex set and the edge set. Additionally, existing approaches focus on preserving graph properties, whereas our objective extends to preserve both graph properties (i.e., relationships between different tables) and statistical properties of relational databases.

2 Preliminaries and Problem Formulation

We introduce notation, represent relational databases through bipartite graphs, review differential privacy and its properties, and provide an overview of our problem formulation.

2.1 Bipartite Graph and Relational Database

To simplify our presentation, we assume that the relational database ℬℬ\mathcal{B} consists of only two tables 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} and 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} (e.g., student and teacher information), each having n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} and n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} rows. The relationship between tables is typically defined through primary and foreign keys. A primary key is a column in a table serving as a unique identifier for each row. A foreign key is a column that establishes a relationship between tables by referencing the primary key of a different table.

We represent the relational database as a bipartite graph ℬ=(𝒟1,𝒟2,𝑩)ℬsubscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2𝑩\mathcal{B}=(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2},\bm{B}) where each record corresponds to a node; the two tables define two distinct sets of nodes; and the relationships between the tables are depicted as edges connecting these nodes. We represent the edges using a bi-adjacency matrix, denoted as 𝑩∈{0,1}n1×n2𝑩superscript01subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\bm{B}\in\{0,1\}^{n_{1}\times n_{2}}, where Bi,j=1subscript𝐵𝑖𝑗1B_{i,j}=1 iff the i-th record from table 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} is connected to the j-th record from table 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} (e.g. if the i-th student is enrolled in the j-th teacher’s course). For each record 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, we represent its degree as the total number of records from the other table connected to 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, denoted by deg⁡(𝒙)degree𝒙\deg(\bm{x}). Finally, we assume the degree of each record is upper bounded by a constant dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max}.

2.2 Differential Privacy

We first recall the definition of differential privacy (DP) [12].

Definition 1.

A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} that takes a relational database as input and returns an output from a set ℛℛ\mathcal{R} satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, if for any adjacent relational databases ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} and all possible subsets 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} of ℛℛ\mathcal{R}, we have

Pr⁡(ℳ​(ℬ)∈𝒪)≤eε​Pr⁡(ℳ​(ℬ′)∈𝒪)+δ.Prℳℬ𝒪superscript𝑒𝜀Prℳsuperscriptℬ′𝒪𝛿\displaystyle\Pr(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B})\in\mathcal{O})\leq e^{\varepsilon}\Pr(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{O})+\delta. (1)

We consider two relational databases ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} adjacent if ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} can be obtained from ℬℬ\mathcal{B} by selecting a table, modifying the values of a single row within this table, and changing all relationships associated with this row.

DP plays a pivotal role in answering statistical queries, with two distinct categories to be considered for relational databases. The first class involves queries pertaining to a single table, say table 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1}. In the context of a student-teacher database, an example would be a query about whether a student is a freshman. If we denote the data domain of table 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} by 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1}, a statistical query can be represented by a function q:𝒳1→{0,1}:𝑞→subscript𝒳101q:\mathcal{X}_{1}\to\{0,1\} and its average over a database is denoted as q​(ℬ)≜1n1​∑𝒙∈𝒟1q​(𝒙)≜𝑞ℬ1subscript𝑛1subscript𝒙subscript𝒟1𝑞𝒙q(\mathcal{B})\triangleq\frac{1}{n_{1}}\sum_{\bm{x}\in\mathcal{D}_{1}}q(\bm{x}). The second class includes cross-table queries, such as whether a teacher and a student belong to the same department. Analogously, these queries are represented by a function q:𝒳1×𝒳2→{0,1}:𝑞→subscript𝒳1subscript𝒳201q:\mathcal{X}_{1}\times\mathcal{X}_{2}\to\{0,1\}. We denote the average of their values over a database by q​(ℬ)≜1𝟏T⋅vec⁡(𝑩)​∑q​(𝒙i,𝒙j)≜𝑞ℬ1⋅superscript1𝑇vec𝑩𝑞subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒙𝑗q(\mathcal{B})\triangleq\frac{1}{\bm{1}^{T}\cdot\operatorname{vec}(\bm{B})}\sum q(\bm{x}_{i},\bm{x}_{j}) where the sum is over (𝒙i,𝒙j)∈𝒟1×𝒟2subscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝒙𝑗subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2(\bm{x}_{i},\bm{x}_{j})\in\mathcal{D}_{1}\times\mathcal{D}_{2} s.t. Bi,j=1subscript𝐵𝑖𝑗1B_{i,j}=1 and vec⁡(⋅)vec⋅\operatorname{vec}(\cdot) converts a matrix into a vector. When (𝒟1,𝒟2)subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2}) are clear from the context, we also express the query in terms of the bi-adjacency matrix 𝑩𝑩\bm{B}.

2.3 Problem Formulation

Our goal is to generate a privacy-preserving synthetic database ℬsyn=(𝒟1syn,𝒟2syn,𝑩syn)subscriptℬsynsuperscriptsubscript𝒟1synsuperscriptsubscript𝒟2synsuperscript𝑩syn\mathcal{B}_{\text{syn}}=(\mathcal{D}_{1}^{\text{syn}},\mathcal{D}_{2}^{\text{syn}},\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}) that preserves both statistical properties and referential integrity of the original relational database. In terms of statistical properties, our aim is to ensure that the marginal distributions of subsets of features in the synthetic data closely align with those of the real data. To achieve this, we revisit the definition of k𝑘k-way marginal query and extend it to suit relational databases.

Definition 2.

Suppose the domain of table 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} has disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} categorical features: 𝒳i=𝒳i,1×⋯​𝒳i,disubscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝒳𝑖1⋯subscript𝒳𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖\mathcal{X}_{i}=\mathcal{X}_{i,1}\times\cdots\mathcal{X}_{i,d_{i}}. We define a k𝑘k-way workload as a subset of k𝑘k features: 𝒮⊆[d1]𝒮delimited-[]subscript𝑑1\mathcal{S}\subseteq[d_{1}] (or 𝒮⊆[d2]𝒮delimited-[]subscript𝑑2\mathcal{S}\subseteq[d_{2}]) with |𝒮|=k𝒮𝑘|\mathcal{S}|=k. Additionally, given a reference value 𝒚𝒚\bm{y}, we define a (single-table) k𝑘k-way marginal query as

where 𝕀𝕀\mathbb{I} is an indicator function. We denote the set of all (cross-table) k𝑘k-way marginal workloads by 𝒲cross,ksubscript𝒲cross𝑘\mathcal{W}_{\text{cross},k} and their associated queries by 𝒬cross,ksubscript𝒬cross𝑘\mathcal{Q}_{\text{cross},k}.

In maintaining referential integrity, we use a linking table to establish relationships. It is designed to store the IDs of synthetic tables: the entry (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is included in this table if 𝑩i,jsyn=1superscriptsubscript𝑩𝑖𝑗syn1\bm{B}_{i,j}^{\text{syn}}=1. Moreover, when the original database exhibits a one-to-many relationship (i.e., a record in the parent table 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} can be related to one or more records in 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2}, but a record in the child 𝒟2subscript𝒟2\mathcal{D}_{2} can be related to only one record in 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1}) or one-to-one relationship111We assume that information about the types of relationships in the original database is publicly available, but it can also be learned differentially privately by examining the degree distribution of each table., we expect the synthetic database to preserve this relationship. Finally, in the case of a one-to-many relationship in the original database, we ensure there are no orphaned rows in the synthetic database. Specifically, we impose the requirement that each record in the child table 𝒟2synsuperscriptsubscript𝒟2syn\mathcal{D}_{2}^{\text{syn}} connects to a record in the parent table 𝒟1synsuperscriptsubscript𝒟1syn\mathcal{D}_{1}^{\text{syn}} (although records in the parent table are permitted to have no associated child records).

3 Main Results

We present our main algorithm (Algorithm 1) for generating privacy-preserving synthetic relational databases. This algorithm can be combined with any existing single-source DP synthetic data mechanisms, adapting them to the relational database context by establishing relationships among individual synthetic tables. Specifically, it learns a bi-adjacency matrix by minimizing approximation errors in cross-table k𝑘k-way marginal queries compared to the original data. Given the inherent large size of the query class, our algorithm employs an iterative approach to identify the queries with the highest approximation errors and refine the bi-adjacency matrix to reduce these errors. Our algorithm is designed for efficiency and scalability, making it well-suited for high-dimensional data. It also ensures referential integrity in the generated synthetic relational data. We end this section by establishing rigorous utility and DP guarantees for our algorithm.

We first create individual synthetic tables 𝒟isynsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖syn\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\text{syn}} by applying any DP mechanisms via black-box access. Our main technical contribution lies in establishing connections among these synthetic tables by constructing a bi-adjacency matrix 𝑩𝑩\bm{B} that links them. We learn this matrix by aligning the cross-table k𝑘k-way marginal queries between the synthetic and original databases. The key observation is that each of these marginal queries can be written as a (fractional) linear function of the bi-adjacency matrix. We formalize this observation in the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

For a relational database (𝒟1,𝒟2,𝐁)subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2𝐁(\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2},\bm{B}) and any k𝑘k-way cross-table query q(𝒮1,𝒮2),(𝐲1,𝐲2)subscript𝑞subscript𝒮1subscript𝒮2subscript𝐲1subscript𝐲2q_{(\mathcal{S}_{1},\mathcal{S}_{2}),(\bm{y}_{1},\bm{y}_{2})}, let 𝟏(𝒮1,𝐲1)∈{0,1}n1subscript1subscript𝒮1subscript𝐲1superscript01subscript𝑛1\bm{1}_{(\mathcal{S}_{1},\bm{y}_{1})}\in\{0,1\}^{n_{1}} denote an indicator vector whose i-th element equals 111 iff the i𝑖i-th record in 𝒟1subscript𝒟1\mathcal{D}_{1} satisfies xi,j=y1,jsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦1𝑗x_{i,j}=y_{1,j} for all j∈𝒮1𝑗subscript𝒮1j\in\mathcal{S}_{1}. Let 𝐪(𝒮1,𝒮2),(𝐲1,𝐲2)=vec⁡(𝟏(𝒮1,𝐲1)⊗𝟏(𝒮2,𝐲2))subscript𝐪subscript𝒮1subscript𝒮2subscript𝐲1subscript𝐲2vectensor-productsubscript1subscript𝒮1subscript𝐲1subscript1subscript𝒮2subscript𝐲2\bm{q}_{(\mathcal{S}_{1},\mathcal{S}_{2}),(\bm{y}_{1},\bm{y}_{2})}=\operatorname{vec}(\bm{1}_{(\mathcal{S}_{1},\bm{y}_{1})}\otimes\bm{1}_{(\mathcal{S}_{2},\bm{y}_{2})}). Then we have:

(3)

Based on the above lemma, we write the cross-table query and its corresponding vector 𝒒(𝒮1,𝒮2),(𝒚1,𝒚2)subscript𝒒subscript𝒮1subscript𝒮2subscript𝒚1subscript𝒚2\bm{q}_{(\mathcal{S}_{1},\mathcal{S}_{2}),(\bm{y}_{1},\bm{y}_{2})} interchangeably. where 𝒃syn=vec⁡(𝑩syn)superscript𝒃synvecsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}}=\operatorname{vec}(\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}) and a𝑎a is the query value computed from the original real data. We present an iterative algorithm for solving the above optimization with DP guarantees. At each iteration, we apply the exponential mechanism to identify cross-table k𝑘k-way workloads whose corresponding queries have the highest approximation errors between synthetic and real databases. Then we add isotropic Gaussian noise to their query values and update the (vectorized) bi-adjacency matrix 𝒃synsuperscript𝒃syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}} to reduce these approximation errors. Specifically, at iteration t𝑡t, we stack all the queries reported so far into a matrix 𝑸^^𝑸\hat{\bm{Q}} and let their noisy answers be a vector 𝒂^^𝒂\hat{\bm{a}}. To update 𝒃synsuperscript𝒃syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}}, we use a mirror descent update with negative entropy mirror [8] to solve the following bounded-variable least-squares problem [42, 7] (see Appendix B for details):

(5)

Suppose 𝒃synsuperscript𝒃syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}} is the output from the preceding procedure, which we reshape into a matrix. Next, we introduce a randomized rounding algorithm to convert 𝒃synsuperscript𝒃syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}} into {0,1}n1syn×n2synsuperscript01subscriptsuperscript𝑛syn1subscriptsuperscript𝑛syn2\{0,1\}^{n^{\text{syn}}_{1}\times n^{\text{syn}}_{2}} for defining the relationship between synthetic tables. Given that 𝒃syn/msynsuperscript𝒃synsuperscript𝑚syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}}/m^{\text{syn}} forms a valid probability distribution over the domain [n1syn]×[n2syn]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑛syn1delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑛syn2[n^{\text{syn}}_{1}]\times[n^{\text{syn}}_{2}], we sample random values from this distribution, rejecting those that have already been selected. We iterate this process until we obtain msynsuperscript𝑚synm^{\text{syn}} distinct random values. These values correspond to the indices of the bi-adjacency matrix 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} whose value is 111.

We outline the above procedure in Algorithm 1 and provide additional details, including our privacy budget tracking, hyper-parameters, the updating rule for mirror descent, and discretization strategy, in Appendix B. We explore strategies for ensuring the scalability of our algorithm for synthesizing large-scale relational databases in Appendix E. We show how our above procedure can be adapted if the original database has a one-to-many relationship in Appendix D. We remark that iterative algorithms are a standard technique for query releasing in the DP literature [see 17, 18, 27, 1, 32, for examples in synthetic data/graph generation] and we extend its applications to establish relationships between synthetic tables. We end this section by establishing DP and utility guarantees for our algorithm.

Theorem 1.

Suppose we use any DP mechanism with privacy budgets (ε1,δ1)subscript𝜀1subscript𝛿1(\varepsilon_{1},\delta_{1}) and (ε2,δ2)subscript𝜀2subscript𝛿2(\varepsilon_{2},\delta_{2}) to generate individual synthetic tables, respectively. Then we apply Algorithm  1 with privacy budget (εrel,δrel)subscript𝜀relsubscript𝛿rel(\varepsilon_{\text{rel}},\delta_{\text{rel}}) to build their relationship. The synthetic relational database satisfies (ε1+ε2+εrel,δ1+δ2+δrel)subscript𝜀1subscript𝜀2subscript𝜀relsubscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿rel(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}+\varepsilon_{\text{rel}},\delta_{1}+\delta_{2}+\delta_{\text{rel}})-DP.

Next, we present a utility theorem that provides an upper bound on the approximation error of cross-table queries using synthetic relational data generated by Algorithm 1.

Theorem 2.

Let 𝐛syn=vec⁡(𝐁syn)superscript𝐛synvecsuperscript𝐁syn\bm{b}^{\text{syn}}=\operatorname{vec}(\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}) be the output of Algorithm 1 (without randomized rounding) for a single iteration across all k𝑘k-way workloads, while 𝐛∗=vec⁡(𝐁∗)superscript𝐛vecsuperscript𝐁\bm{b}^{*}=\operatorname{vec}(\bm{B}^{*}) denotes the optimal bi-adjacency matrix achievable for the synthetic individual tables without any privacy constraints. We stack all the query vectors as matrices 𝐐𝐐\bm{Q} and 𝐐^^𝐐\hat{\bm{Q}} for the original and synthetic tables, respectively. Let 𝐚𝐚\bm{a} be the true answers of all queries computed from the original database. With high probability,

‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃syn−𝒂‖22|𝒲cross,k|≤8​‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗−𝒂‖22|𝒲cross,k|+O​(dmaxm​ρrel).superscriptsubscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃syn𝒂22subscript𝒲cross𝑘8superscriptsubscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃𝒂22subscript𝒲cross𝑘𝑂subscript𝑑max𝑚subscript𝜌rel\displaystyle\frac{\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{\text{syn}}-\bm{a}\right\|_{2}^{2}}{|\mathcal{W}_{\text{cross},k}|}\leq 8\frac{\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}-\bm{a}\right\|_{2}^{2}}{|\mathcal{W}_{\text{cross},k}|}+O\left(\frac{d_{\text{max}}}{m\sqrt{\rho_{\text{rel}}}}\right).

where ρrel=(εrel+log⁡1δrel−log⁡1δrel)2subscript𝜌relsuperscriptsubscript𝜀rellog1subscript𝛿rellog1subscript𝛿rel2\rho_{\text{rel}}=\left(\sqrt{\varepsilon_{\text{rel}}+\operatorname{log}\frac{1}{\delta_{\text{rel}}}}-\sqrt{\operatorname{log}\frac{1}{\delta_{\text{rel}}}}\right)^{2} and we ignore logarithmic terms.

The theorem above bounds the per-workload squared error in estimating cross-table queries using synthetic data from Algorithm 1. This upper bound consists of the optimal error without privacy constraints and an additional error term. The optimal error depends on the quality of the individual synthetic tables and the selected privacy mechanism. If the synthetic tables matched the original, the optimal error would be zero. The additional error term is influenced by three factors: m𝑚m (number of relationships in the original database), dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} (maximum relationships per record), and ρrelsubscript𝜌rel\rho_{\text{rel}} (privacy parameter). With a fixed dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} and ρrelsubscript𝜌rel\rho_{\text{rel}}, as the number of relationships increases, this error term diminishes. Unlike existing utility theorems that depend on the data domain size |𝒳i|subscript𝒳𝑖|\mathcal{X}_{i}| for categorical features, which can be large, we avoid this reliance in our theorem by using the “marginal trick” [see Appendix D.4 in 27].

4 Conclusion and Limitations

In this paper, we investigated synthetic relational database generation with DP guarantees. We proposed an iterative algorithm that combines with preexisting single-table generation mechanisms to maintain cross-table statistical properties and referential integrity and derived rigorous utility guarantees for it. We hope our efforts inspire new research and push the frontiers of DP synthetic data toward practical scenarios.

There are several intriguing directions worth exploring further. First, we assumed that every record in the relational database must be kept private, but exploring cases where only specific tables contain personal private information would be interesting. For instance, in education data, teacher and student information might require privacy-preserving, while course and department information is often publicly available. Second, our algorithm generates individual synthetic tables and uses an iterative algorithm to establish relationships. An extension would be integrating synthetic table generation into the iterative algorithm, learning both single-table and cross-table queries simultaneously. This may require white-box access to the generative models. Lastly, while we generate synthetic relational databases focused on preserving low-order marginal distributions, other criteria like logical consistency, temporal dynamics, and user-defined constraints are also worthy of exploration.

Appendix A Background on Differential Privacy (DP)

We recall the concept of (zero) concentrated differential privacy [9, 43]. It will be used in the proof of Theorem 1 for establishing DP guarantees for our algorithm.

Definition 3.

(Zero concentrated differential privacy (zCDP)). A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-zero Concentrated Differential Privacy (zCDP) if for all pairs of neighboring relational databases ℬ,ℬ′ℬsuperscriptℬ′\mathcal{B},\mathcal{B}^{\prime}, and for all α∈(1,∞)𝛼1\alpha\in(1,\infty) :

𝔻α​(ℳ​(ℬ),ℳ​(ℬ))≤ρ​αsubscript𝔻𝛼ℳℬℳℬ𝜌𝛼\mathbb{D}_{\alpha}\left(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}),\mathcal{M}\left(\mathcal{B}\right)\right)\leq\rho\alpha

where 𝔻α​(ℳ​(ℬ),ℳ​(ℬ′))subscript𝔻𝛼ℳℬℳsuperscriptℬ′\mathbb{D}_{\alpha}\left(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}),\mathcal{M}\left(\mathcal{B}^{\prime}\right)\right) denotes the α𝛼\alpha-Renyi divergence between the distributions of ℳ​(ℬ)ℳℬ\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B}) and ℳ​(ℬ′)ℳsuperscriptℬ′\mathcal{M}\left(\mathcal{B}^{\prime}\right).

zCDP has nice composition and post-processing properties.

Lemma 2.

(Adaptive composition). Let ℳ1,⋯,ℳTsubscriptℳ1⋯subscriptℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}_{1},\cdots,\mathcal{M}_{T} be ρ1,⋯,ρTsubscript𝜌1⋯subscript𝜌𝑇\rho_{1},\cdots,\rho_{T}-zCDP, respectively. Suppose ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is an adaptive composition of ℳ1,⋯,ℳTsubscriptℳ1⋯subscriptℳ𝑇\mathcal{M}_{1},\cdots,\mathcal{M}_{T}. Then ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies (∑ρi)subscript𝜌𝑖(\sum\rho_{i})-zCDP.

Lemma 3.

(Post-processing). Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} be a ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP mechanism. Suppose f𝑓f is any (possibly randomized) function. Then ℳ′​(ℬ)=f​(ℳ​(ℬ))superscriptℳ′ℬ𝑓ℳℬ\mathcal{M}^{\prime}(\mathcal{B})=f(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B})) satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP.

Lemma 4.

(Relation between zCDP and DP.) If ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP, then it also satisfies (ρ+2​ρ​log⁡(1/δ),δ)𝜌2𝜌1𝛿𝛿(\rho+2\sqrt{\rho\log(1/\delta)},\delta)-DP for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0.

Next, we recall two basic privacy mechanisms: Gaussian and exponential mechanisms. To start with, we define the Lpsubscript𝐿𝑝L_{p} sensitivity of a function f𝑓f as

Δp​(f)≜supℬ∼ℬ′‖f​(ℬ)−f​(ℬ′)‖p,≜subscriptΔ𝑝𝑓subscriptsupremumsimilar-toℬsuperscriptℬ′subscriptnorm𝑓ℬ𝑓superscriptℬ′𝑝\displaystyle\Delta_{p}(f)\triangleq\sup_{\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{B}^{\prime}}\|f(\mathcal{B})-f(\mathcal{B}^{\prime})\|_{p}, (6)

where ℬ∼ℬ′similar-toℬsuperscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{B}^{\prime} are two neighboring databases.

Lemma 5.

(Gaussian Mechanism). Given a function f𝑓f, the Gaussian mechanism is defined as ℳ​(ℬ)=f​(ℬ)+σ​Δ2​(f)​Nℳℬ𝑓ℬ𝜎subscriptΔ2𝑓𝑁\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B})=f(\mathcal{B})+\sigma\Delta_{2}(f)N where N𝑁N is a random vector drawn from 𝒩​(𝟎,𝐈)𝒩0𝐈\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\bm{I}). Then ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies 12​σ212superscript𝜎2\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}-zCDP.

Finally, we recall the exponential mechanism. For a 𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾\mathsf{score} function and a set 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}, we define its sensitivity by

Δ​(𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾)≜supℬ∼ℬ′maxo∈𝒪⁡|𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾​(ℬ,o)−𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾​(ℬ′,o)|.≜Δ𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾subscriptsupremumsimilar-toℬsuperscriptℬ′subscript𝑜𝒪𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾ℬ𝑜𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾superscriptℬ′𝑜\displaystyle\Delta(\mathsf{score})\triangleq\sup_{\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{B}^{\prime}}\max_{o\in\mathcal{O}}|\mathsf{score}(\mathcal{B},o)-\mathsf{score}(\mathcal{B}^{\prime},o)|. (7)
Lemma 6.

(Exponential Mechanism). Given a 𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾\mathsf{score} function and the set 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} of all possible outputs, the exponential mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is a randomized mechanism defined by

Pr⁡(ℳ​(ℬ)=o)∝exp⁡(ϵ2​Δ​(𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾)​𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾​(ℬ,o)),∀o∈𝒪.formulae-sequenceproportional-toPrℳℬ𝑜italic-ϵ2Δ𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾ℬ𝑜for-all𝑜𝒪\displaystyle\Pr(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{B})=o)\propto\exp\left(\frac{\epsilon}{2\Delta(\mathsf{score})}\mathsf{score}(\mathcal{B},o)\right),\quad\forall o\in\mathcal{O}. (8)

Then ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ϵ28superscriptitalic-ϵ28\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{8}-zCDP.

Appendix C Omitted Proofs

We start this section by proving the DP guarantee for our main algorithm. We recall Theorem 1 below for reference.

Theorem 3.

Suppose we use any DP mechanism with privacy budgets (ε1,δ1)subscript𝜀1subscript𝛿1(\varepsilon_{1},\delta_{1}) and (ε2,δ2)subscript𝜀2subscript𝛿2(\varepsilon_{2},\delta_{2}) to generate individual synthetic tables, respectively. Then we apply Algorithm  1 with privacy budget (εrel,δrel)subscript𝜀relsubscript𝛿rel(\varepsilon_{\text{rel}},\delta_{\text{rel}}) to build their relationship. The synthetic relational database satisfies (ε1+ε2+εrel,δ1+δ2+δrel)subscript𝜀1subscript𝜀2subscript𝜀relsubscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2subscript𝛿rel(\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}+\varepsilon_{\text{rel}},\delta_{1}+\delta_{2}+\delta_{\text{rel}})-DP, where εrel​(δrel)≤ρrel+2​ρrel​log⁡(1/δrel)subscript𝜀relsubscript𝛿relsubscript𝜌rel2subscript𝜌rel1subscript𝛿rel\varepsilon_{\text{rel}}(\delta_{\text{rel}})\leq\rho_{\text{rel}}+2\sqrt{\rho_{\text{rel}}\log(1/\delta_{\text{rel}})}. This condition can be achieved by choosing ρrel=(log⁡(1/δrel)+ϵrel−log⁡(1/δrel))2subscript𝜌relsuperscript1subscript𝛿relsubscriptitalic-ϵrel1subscript𝛿rel2\rho_{\text{rel}}=\left(\sqrt{\log(1/\delta_{\text{rel}})+\epsilon_{\text{rel}}}-\sqrt{\log(1/\delta_{\text{rel}})}\right)^{2}.

Proof.

At each iteration, Algorithm  1 makes K𝐾K call to the exponential mechanism and K𝐾K call to the Gaussian mechanism. The exponential mechanism uses the score function:

𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾​(w)=12​‖Pw​(ℬ)−Pw​(ℬsyn)‖1.𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾𝑤12subscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑤ℬsubscript𝑃𝑤superscriptℬsyn1\displaystyle\mathsf{score}(w)=\frac{1}{2}\|P_{w}(\mathcal{B})-P_{w}(\mathcal{B}^{\text{syn}})\|_{1}. (9)

Recall that we consider two relational databases ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} adjacent if ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} can be obtained from ℬℬ\mathcal{B} by selecting a table, modifying the values of a single row within this table, and changing all relationship associated with this row. We focus on the setting of bounded DP so both ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} have m𝑚m relationships. Additionally, we assume each record can have a relationship with at most dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} records in the other table. Hence, for any workload w𝑤w, the total variance distance between the empirical distributions of ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and ℬ′superscriptℬ′\mathcal{B}^{\prime} on w𝑤w has an upper bound:

12​‖Pw​(ℬ)−Pw​(ℬ′)‖≤dmaxm.12normsubscript𝑃𝑤ℬsubscript𝑃𝑤superscriptℬ′subscript𝑑𝑚\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\|P_{w}(\mathcal{B})-P_{w}(\mathcal{B}^{\prime})\|\leq\frac{d_{\max}}{m}. (10)

By the triangle inequality, we can upper bounded the sensitivity of 𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾𝗌𝖼𝗈𝗋𝖾\mathsf{score} by dmaxmsubscript𝑑𝑚\frac{d_{\max}}{m}. Similarly, for each workload w𝑤w, we can upper bound the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} sensitivity of each empirical distribution Pw​(B)subscript𝑃𝑤𝐵P_{w}(B) by 2​dmaxm2subscript𝑑𝑚\frac{\sqrt{2}d_{\max}}{m}. By Lemmas 5 and  6, at each iteration, the exponential and Gaussian mechanisms satisfy K2​α⋅ϵ02⋅𝐾2𝛼superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\frac{K}{2}\alpha\cdot\epsilon_{0}^{2}-zCDP and K2​(1−α)⋅ϵ02⋅𝐾21𝛼superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\frac{K}{2}(1-\alpha)\cdot\epsilon_{0}^{2}-zCDP, respectively. The composition theorem in Lemma 2 ensures that Algorithm  1 satisfies K​T​(α+(1−α))2​ϵ02𝐾𝑇𝛼1𝛼2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\frac{KT(\alpha+(1-\alpha))}{2}\epsilon_{0}^{2}-zCDP. Recall that we chose ϵ0=2​ρrelK​Tsubscriptitalic-ϵ02subscript𝜌rel𝐾𝑇\epsilon_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{2\rho_{\text{rel}}}{KT}}. Hence, Algorithm 1 satisfies ρrelsubscript𝜌rel\rho_{\text{rel}}-zCDP. As a result, Lemma 4 yields that it also satisfies (ρrel+2​ρrel​log⁡(1/δ),δ)subscript𝜌rel2subscript𝜌rel1𝛿𝛿(\rho_{\text{rel}}+2\sqrt{\rho_{\text{rel}}\log(1/\delta)},\delta)-DP. In particular, if we choose ρrel=(log⁡(1/δrel)+ϵrel−log⁡(1/δrel))2subscript𝜌relsuperscript1subscript𝛿relsubscriptitalic-ϵrel1subscript𝛿rel2\rho_{\text{rel}}=\left(\sqrt{\log(1/\delta_{\text{rel}})+\epsilon_{\text{rel}}}-\sqrt{\log(1/\delta_{\text{rel}})}\right)^{2}, then Algorithm 1 will satisfy (ϵrel,δrel)subscriptitalic-ϵrelsubscript𝛿rel(\epsilon_{\text{rel}},\delta_{\text{rel}})-DP. ∎

Below, we provide a more rigorous statement of Theorem  2 along with its proof.

We first prove some lemmas that will be used in the proof of Theorem 4.

Lemma 7.

(Contractive property of convex sets projection [40]) Let 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} be a non-empty closed convex subset of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, then for any 𝐱1,𝐱2subscript𝐱1subscript𝐱2\bm{x}_{1},\bm{x}_{2} if we denote their projections by 𝐲1,𝐲2subscript𝐲1subscript𝐲2\bm{y}_{1},\bm{y}_{2} respectively, i.e. 𝐲i=arg⁡min𝐲∈𝒴⁡‖𝐱i−𝐲‖22subscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐲𝒴superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖𝐲22\bm{y}_{i}=\arg\min_{\bm{y}\in\mathcal{Y}}\|\bm{x}_{i}-\bm{y}\|_{2}^{2}, then we have

‖𝒚1−𝒚2‖22≤‖𝒙1−𝒙2‖22.superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒚1subscript𝒚222superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒙1subscript𝒙222\|\bm{y}_{1}-\bm{y}_{2}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|\bm{x}_{1}-\bm{x}_{2}\|_{2}^{2}.
Proof.

Let 𝒗≜𝒚2−𝒚2≠o≜𝒗subscript𝒚2subscript𝒚2𝑜\bm{v}\triangleq\bm{y}_{2}-\bm{y}_{2}\neq o. The function f𝑓f defined by f​(t)≜|𝒙1−(𝒚1+t​𝒗)|2≜𝑓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙1subscript𝒚1𝑡𝒗2f(t)\triangleq|\bm{x}_{1}-(\bm{y}_{1}+t\bm{v})|^{2} for t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1] has a minimum at t=0𝑡0t=0, hence f′​(0)≥0superscript𝑓′00f^{\prime}(0)\geq 0. Similarly we obtain ⟨𝒙2−𝒚2,𝒗⟩≥0subscript𝒙2subscript𝒚2𝒗0\langle\bm{x}_{2}-\bm{y}_{2},\bm{v}\rangle\geq 0. Lemma 8.

Let 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} be a non-empty closed set. For any 𝐱𝐱\bm{x}, we denote its projection onto 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} by 𝐲∗superscript𝐲\bm{y}^{*}, i.e. 𝐲∗=arg⁡min𝐲∈𝒴⁡‖𝐱−𝐲‖22superscript𝐲subscript𝐲𝒴superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱𝐲22\bm{y}^{*}=\arg\min_{\bm{y}\in\mathcal{Y}}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|_{2}^{2}. ‖𝒚∗−𝒚′‖22≤2​⟨𝒚∗−𝒚′,𝒙−𝒚′⟩.superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒚superscript𝒚′222superscript𝒚superscript𝒚′𝒙superscript𝒚′\|\bm{y}^{*}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}\leq 2\langle\bm{y}^{*}-\bm{y}^{\prime},\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\rangle.
Proof.

By the optimality of 𝒚∗superscript𝒚\bm{y}^{*} and 𝒚′∈𝒴superscript𝒚′𝒴\bm{y}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Y}, we have

‖𝒙−𝒚∗‖22≤‖𝒙−𝒚′‖22.superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒙superscript𝒚22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒙superscript𝒚′22\displaystyle\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{*}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}.

‖𝒙−𝒚′‖22+2​⟨𝒙−𝒚′,𝒚′−𝒚∗⟩+‖𝒚′−𝒚∗‖22≤‖𝒙−𝒚′‖22,superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒙superscript𝒚′222𝒙superscript𝒚′superscript𝒚′superscript𝒚superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒚′superscript𝒚22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒙superscript𝒚′22\displaystyle\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}+2\langle\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{\prime},\bm{y}^{\prime}-\bm{y}^{*}\rangle+\|\bm{y}^{\prime}-\bm{y}^{*}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2},

which yields the desired inequality. ∎

The following lemma is a standard result from concentration inequalities.

Lemma 9.

≤∑i=1nℙ​{Xi≥u}absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛ℙsubscript𝑋𝑖𝑢\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{P}\left\{X_{i}\geq u\right\}
≤n​e−u22​σ2=exp⁡(−t).absent𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝑢22superscript𝜎2𝑡\displaystyle\leq ne^{-\frac{u^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}}=\exp(-t).

∎

Proof of Theorem  4.

We define Nsyn=n1syn⋅n2synsuperscript𝑁syn⋅superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2synN^{\text{syn}}=n_{1}^{\text{syn}}\cdot n_{2}^{\text{syn}}. Additionally, we define the projection set with respect to 𝑸^^𝑸\hat{\bm{Q}} as

‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃^−𝒂‖2≤‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃^−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃~‖2+‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃~−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗‖2+‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗−𝒂‖2.subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸^𝒃𝒂2subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸^𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃2subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃2subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃𝒂2\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\hat{\bm{b}}-\bm{a}\right\|_{2}\leq\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\hat{\bm{b}}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}\right\|_{2}+\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\|_{2}+\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}-\bm{a}\right\|_{2}.

‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃^−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃~‖2≤‖(𝒂+𝒘)−(1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗+𝒘)‖2=‖𝒂−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗‖2.subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸^𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃2subscriptnorm𝒂𝒘1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃𝒘2subscriptnorm𝒂1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃2\displaystyle\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\hat{\bm{b}}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}\right\|_{2}\leq\left\|(\bm{a}+\bm{w})-(\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}+\bm{w})\right\|_{2}=\left\|\bm{a}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\|_{2}.

‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃^−𝒂‖2≤2​‖𝒂−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗‖2+‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃~−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗‖2.subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸^𝒃𝒂22subscriptnorm𝒂1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃2subscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃2\displaystyle\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\hat{\bm{b}}-\bm{a}\right\|_{2}\leq 2\left\|\bm{a}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\|_{2}+\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\|_{2}. (13)

By the definition of 𝒃~~𝒃\widetilde{\bm{b}} in (12) and Lemma 8, we have

‖1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃~−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗‖22superscriptsubscriptnorm1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃22\displaystyle\left\|\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\|_{2}^{2} ≤2msyn​⟨𝑸^​𝒃~−𝑸^​𝒃∗,(1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗+𝒘)−1msyn​𝑸^​𝒃∗⟩absent2superscript𝑚syn^𝑸~𝒃^𝑸superscript𝒃1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃𝒘1superscript𝑚syn^𝑸superscript𝒃\displaystyle\leq\frac{2}{m^{\text{syn}}}\left\langle\hat{\bm{Q}}\widetilde{\bm{b}}-\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*},(\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}+\bm{w})-\frac{1}{m^{\text{syn}}}\hat{\bm{Q}}\bm{b}^{*}\right\rangle

Appendix D Discretization Strategies for Preserving Referential Integrity

Algorithm 6 can be done more efficiently based on properties of exponential random variables.

The time complexity of this method is O​(N​log⁡N)𝑂𝑁𝑁O(N\log N) whereas the simple-and-reject approach presented in Algorithm 6 takes at least Ω​(N2)Ωsuperscript𝑁2\Omega\left(N^{2}\right) time.

Theorem 5.

Algorithms 6 and 7 are equivalent.

Proof.

To prove that these two procedures are equivalent, we must first remember the following properties of exponential random variables.

  1. 1.

    If X𝑋X is exponential with parameter λ𝜆\lambda, and Y𝑌Y is independently exponential with parameter μ𝜇\mu, then min⁡(X,Y)𝑋𝑌\min(X,Y) is exponential with parameter λ+μ𝜆𝜇\lambda+\mu.

  2. 2.

    With the same assumptions as the last point, P​(X<Y)=λλ+μ𝑃𝑋𝑌𝜆𝜆𝜇P(X<Y)=\frac{\lambda}{\lambda+\mu}.

  3. 3.

    The exponential distribution is memoryless, in the sense that P​(X≤s+t​∣X>​t)=P​(X≤s)𝑃𝑋𝑠𝑡ket𝑋𝑡𝑃𝑋𝑠P(X\leq s+t\mid X>t)=P(X\leq s) for all s,t≥0𝑠𝑡0s,t\geq 0.

This implies that, for example, the probability that the first sampled element is X1subscript𝑋1X_{1} is

P​(X1<min⁡(X2,X3,…,XN))=𝒃^1r𝒃^1r+(𝒃^2r+⋯+𝒃^Nr).𝑃subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2subscript𝑋3…subscript𝑋𝑁subscriptsuperscript^𝒃𝑟1subscriptsuperscript^𝒃𝑟1subscriptsuperscript^𝒃𝑟2⋯subscriptsuperscript^𝒃𝑟𝑁P(X_{1}<\min(X_{2},X_{3},\ldots,X_{N}))=\frac{\hat{\bm{b}}^{r}_{1}}{\hat{\bm{b}}^{r}_{1}+\left(\hat{\bm{b}}^{r}_{2}+\cdots+\hat{\bm{b}}^{r}_{N}\right)}.

Then, for subsequent samples, you can do a similar calculation where you leave 𝒃^1rsubscriptsuperscript^𝒃𝑟1\hat{\bm{b}}^{r}_{1} out (because of memorylessness) and conclude that the probability of each potential outcome happening is similar in both algorithms. ∎

Now, we turn our attention to an adapted version of the primary algorithm tailored for databases where each entry in the first table is linked to just one entry in the second table, known as one-to-many databases. This adaptation introduces two notable distinctions from the main algorithm. Firstly, we modify the projection algorithm to seek solutions that maintain a fixed degree of one for each entry in the first dataset. We introduce a linear equation for each entry into the projection problem to accomplish this. It is worth mentioning that this adjusted projection step and the additional linear constraints remain computationally manageable and can be solved using mirror descent. Secondly, in Algorithm 8, we adopt a strategy that selects precisely one edge from the set of edges connected to each entry in the initial dataset. This approach yields an unbiased estimator for each query.

Appendix E Extension for Improving Scalability

In this section, we introduce an extension of our main algorithm (Algorithm 1) for synthesizing large-scale relational databases. The key idea is to leverage the sparsity of the bi-adjacency matrix 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}—we can store 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} as a sparse matrix and update a portion of its elements at each iteration. We present the extended algorithm in Algorithm 9 and illustrate its difference compared with Algorithm 1 in Figure 1.

Recall that the dimension of the bi-adjacency matrix 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} is n1syn×n2synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2synn_{1}^{\text{syn}}\times n_{2}^{\text{syn}}, which could result in scalability issues when generating large-scale synthetic tables. For this purpose, we observe that the nonzero entries of 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} typically scale with O​(n1syn+n2syn)𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2synO(n_{1}^{\text{syn}}+n_{2}^{\text{syn}}). For example, in the student-teacher example, each student may only be in at most 101010 classes, upper bounding the number of non-zero entries to grow linearly with the size of the students’ synthetic table.

We propose to only learn part of the bi-adjacency matrix at each iteration. We randomly select a fraction α𝛼\alpha of the records in each synthetic table and we slice the 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} to only include the relationships to 𝑩slicesynsubscriptsuperscript𝑩synslice\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}_{\text{slice}} between the selected records in each table. We run a similar mirror-descent algorithm to optimize the relationships between just the selected records on the queries selected in this iteration. We then re-insert these newly learned relationships into 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} for the next iteration. This allows the size of the vector on which mirror descent is performed to be reduced to α2​n1syn×n2synsuperscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2syn\alpha^{2}n_{1}^{\text{syn}}\times n_{2}^{\text{syn}}, saving on runtime and memory. Additionally, we observed in experiments that this approach can even produce higher fidelity results, potentially by helping mitigate some of the “over-relaxation” incurred by the mirror descent algorithm.

To implement this algorithm, we begin by storing the bi-adjacency matrix as a sparse matrix 𝑩syn∈{0,1}n1syn×n2synsuperscript𝑩synsuperscript01superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}}\in\{0,1\}^{n_{1}^{\text{syn}}\times n_{2}^{\text{syn}}}. We also introduce a new parameter α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, indicating which fraction of relations are learned in each iteration. Next, we define the slicing operation, which will be used to extract elements of 𝑩synsuperscript𝑩syn\bm{B}^{\text{syn}} before running the mirror-descent algorithm.

Definition 4.

Given a matrix 𝑴∈ℝn1×n2𝑴superscriptℝsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\bm{M}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}\times n_{2}} and vectors 𝒗1∈{0,1}n1subscript𝒗1superscript01subscript𝑛1\bm{v}_{1}\in\{0,1\}^{n_{1}}, 𝒗2∈{0,1}n2subscript𝒗2superscript01subscript𝑛2\bm{v}_{2}\in\{0,1\}^{n_{2}}, we denote the slicing operation by 𝑴​[𝒗1,𝒗2]𝑴superscript𝒗1superscript𝒗2\bm{M}\left[\bm{v}^{1},\bm{v}^{2}\right]. This operation yields a matrix with sum⁡(𝒗1slice)sumsubscriptsuperscript𝒗slice1\operatorname{sum}({\bm{v}^{\text{slice}}_{1}}) rows and sum⁡(𝒗2slice)sumsubscriptsuperscript𝒗slice2\operatorname{sum}({\bm{v}^{\text{slice}}_{2}}) columns. The (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) entry of this matrix corresponds to the (vi1,vj2)subscriptsuperscript𝑣1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑣2𝑗(v^{1}_{i},v^{2}_{j}) entry of 𝑴𝑴\bm{M}, where vi1subscriptsuperscript𝑣1𝑖v^{1}_{i} is defined as the i𝑖i-th nonzero entry of 𝒗1superscript𝒗1\bm{v}^{1} (similarly for vi2subscriptsuperscript𝑣2𝑖v^{2}_{i}).

The time and space complexity of the algorithm are reduced from O​(T​n1syn​n2syn)𝑂𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2synO(Tn_{1}^{\text{syn}}n_{2}^{\text{syn}}) to O​(T​α2​n1syn​n2syn)𝑂𝑇superscript𝛼2superscriptsubscript𝑛1synsuperscriptsubscript𝑛2synO(T\alpha^{2}n_{1}^{\text{syn}}n_{2}^{\text{syn}}) by this strategy. Hence, by choosing smaller α𝛼\alpha, we can reduce the time complexity of the algorithm.
